title: Documentation as Communication
content: Written documentation extends communication across time and distance. Write for the reader who wasn't there. Be specific, factual, and complete. Avoid jargon unknown to potential readers. Good documentation answers questions before they're asked.

mcq.question: You're documenting an incident. 'We fixed the problem' versus 'Replaced failed bearing on pump P-103, restored operation at 1430.' Which is better?

options.B: Second—it's specific and useful for future reference

mcq.explanation: Specific documentation serves multiple purposes: troubleshooting similar issues, maintenance history, regulatory compliance, knowledge transfer. Vague documentation helps no one.

openQuestions: What makes documentation useful versus checkbox compliance?
How do you decide what level of detail to include?
